awd_titl_txt: Development and Empirical Recovery for a Learning Progression-Based Assessment of the Function Concept
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will design an assessment based on learning progressions for the concept of function. A learning progression describes how students develop understanding of a topic over time. Function is a critical concept for algebra learning and understanding. The goal of the assessment and learning progression design in this project is to specifically incorporate findings about the learning of students traditionally under-served and under-performing in algebra courses. The project will include accounting for the social and cultural experiences of the middle and high school students when creating assessment tasks. The resources developed should impact mathematics instruction (especially for algebra courses) by creating a learning progression which captures the range of student performance and appropriately places them at distinct levels of performance. The important contribution of the work is the development of a learning progression and related assessment tasks that account for the experiences of students often under-served in mathematics. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The learning progression development will begin by comparing and integrating existing learning progressions and current research on function learning. This project will develop an assessment of student knowledge of function based on learning progressions via empirical recovery (looking for the reconstruction of theoretical levels of the learning theory). Empirical recovery is the process through which data will be collected that reconstruct the various levels, stages, or sequences of said learning progression. The development of tasks and task models will include testing computer-delivered, interactive tasks and rubrics that can be used for human and automated scoring (depending on the task). Item response theory methods will be used to evaluate the assessment tasks' incorporation of the learning progression.

por.por_cntn:
The project?s goals were to validate a learning progression (LP) for the function concept and include in this research students in communities historically underserved by mathematics education. Our premise was that this approach would enhance validity and equity as well as enable us to deliver an LP with the potential to support learning of a diverse pool of students. 

An LP is a theory of how student thinking develops, from early intuitions to nuanced understanding. A validated LP has the potential to serve as guide for teachers to inform instruction. Another aim was to examine whether there is empirical support for the ordering of levels in the LP. 

While central to higher mathematics, the function concept can be challenging for students to develop. Several streams of earlier work suggested the need for a three-stranded LP. The Algebra Project?s Road Coloring curriculum module by Budzban and Moses focuses on functions from finite sets to finite sets and informed the development of the Finite-to-Finite strand. The Algebra Project?s Symmetry, Shape, and Groups curriculum module by Henderson approaches geometric transformations as functions and informed the development of the Geometry strand. Finally, a preliminary ETS LP focusing on linear, quadratic, and exponential functions informed the development of the Traditional strand. 

An expert panel reviewed a draft LP from which ETS assessment specialists authored multi-item tasks. We used focus groups and cognitive interviews to evaluate the tasks. Handling many of the cognitive interviews were Young People?s Project staff, who have experience as near-peer mentors. During the interviews, students thought aloud and responded to retrospective questions. The primary goals of the interviews were to better understand the students' thought processes while performing a task, inform task development, and strengthen future student interactions around the task content material. Focus group and cognitive interview findings informed task revisions. 

We delivered tasks from the Finite-to-Finite and Traditional strands via computer in a pilot with 1,102 students. The pilot included 26 multi-item tasks (for a total of 120 items). 

We developed rubrics to score responses with respect to the LP. We computed statistics including those for reliability for each item in the tasks. We developed Provisional Wright maps to examine the ordering of levels within items, but they were largely inconclusive due to the sample size. In its review of the items and statistics, the project team included team members who could provide their perspectives from having conducted interviews. We examined tasks that had low reliability and very difficult items, and as a result, dropped two tasks, revised many others, and created six new tasks, for a total of 30 multi-item tasks for a planned field test. For the field test, we programmed the tasks and began administration, but stopped due to school closures at the outset of the COVID-19 pandemic. 

Unable to complete the field test, we examined the pilot data from the perspective of our original research question: Is there empirical support for the ordering of levels within the LP? Although unable to answer this question within items, we were able to approach it across items. We classified each of the 120 items into one of nine mathematical themes. We confirmed empirically that items in the Extending patterns theme (an early skill in the LP) were among the easiest, while items in the Composition and Representing as an expression/equation themes (later skills in the LP) were among the most difficult. This provides some partial empirical support of the LP, although there is substantial variation within each theme. A Wright map (below) shows that the easier items are toward the bottom of the map and more difficult items are at the top. We sorted the items by mathematical theme, and by difficulty within theme. The patterns discussed above are evident from the map. 

The map also indicates the corresponding strand for each item. In the Translating representations and Is it a function themes, Finite-to-Finite strand items tend to be easier than Traditional strand items. This may have something to do with the items in each of these strands or it may be because the Road Coloring curriculum module emphasizes these themes.
